title: Quotation of the Day: How Many Men in Albuquerque? Tell You in 2023, Census Pledges.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 30, 2022.
content: “Everything is delayed. The census is delayed. Supply chains are delayed. Good luck getting a couch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy A. Ruhling
title: How the Executive Director of the Queens Botanical Garden Spends Her Sundays
description: Evie Hantzopoulos has lived in Astoria since 1999. She is committed to the neighborhood, shopping, socializing and volunteering locally.
content: As the first new executive director of the Queens Botanical Garden in nearly three decades, Evie Hantzopoulos is leading the Flushing-based nonprofit through a period of expansion that includes the building of a $32 million education center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Jail Officer and Murder Suspect Missing After Heading to Unfounded Appointment
description: The authorities in Alabama said it was unclear whether the officer had helped the inmate escape or whether she had been kidnapped.
content: Alabama authorities are searching for a corrections officer and a murder suspect who were last seen on Friday leaving the jail for what should have been a three-minute drive to the county courthouse for an appointment that turned out not to exist, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Nebraska Candidate for Governor Accused of Second Groping Incident at 2019 Dinner
description: Charles W. Herbster, who has been endorsed by Donald Trump for Nebraska governor, was accused of groping a second woman at a 2019 Republican fund-raising event. He denies both allegations.
content: A second woman has publicly accused Charles W. Herbster, the Republican candidate for governor in Nebraska endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, of groping her at a 2019 Republican fund-raising dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Naomi Judd, of Grammy-Winning The Judds, Dies at 76
description: The country music duo, made up of Naomi and Wynonna Judd, was to be inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame on Sunday.
content: Naomi Judd, of the Grammy-winning duo The Judds and the mother of Wynonna and Ashley Judd, died on Saturday. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Kate Zernike
title: Connecticut Moves to Blunt Impact of Other States’ Anti-Abortion Laws
description: The state is among several acting to strengthen abortion rights protections as a Supreme Court ruling that could overturn Roe v. Wade looms.
content: Connecticut lawmakers approved a bill late Friday night that takes direct aim at states that have passed aggressive anti-abortion laws as the country prepares for a Supreme Court ruling this summer that could weaken or overturn the constitutional right to abortion enshrined in Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Mike Isaac
title: How Twitter’s Board Went From Fighting Elon Musk to Accepting Him
description: It’s highly unusual to move from a “poison pill” to a $44 billion deal in under two weeks. But Twitter’s board ran out of options.
content: Twitter’s board had reached the end of the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Ohio Primary and the Return of the Republican Civil War
description: How the divides of the party’s 2016 primary campaign have risen fully to the surface again.
content: Why has the Ohio Republican Senate primary, which reaches its conclusion Tuesday, been so interesting (if not always edifying) to watch? In part, because it’s the first time the divides of the party’s 2016 primary campaign have risen fully to the surface again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arya Sundaram
title: Arkansas Sues Family Dollar Over Persistent Rodent Infestation
description: The company knew of the infestation at a West Memphis, Ark., distribution center but continued to distribute its products anyway, according to a suit filed by the state attorney general.
content: The Arkansas state attorney general is suing the value-store chain Family Dollar, claiming the company knew of a “massive and long-lasting” rodent infestation at a West Memphis distribution center but still continued to sell potentially contaminated products that were stored there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carey Gillam and Sophie Kasakove
title: Tornado Tears Through City in Kansas, Causing Extensive Damage
description: No fatalities were reported in the city of Andover, near Wichita, but up to 1,000 structures may have been affected, officials said.
content: On Friday night, Lindsay Triplett and her family in Andover, Kan., received emergency alarms on their cellphones. Minutes later, the roof of their home vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart Dybek
title: Slice-of-Life Stories Shot Through With Dark Humor
description: Set mostly in western Ireland, Colin Barrett’s second collection is a painterly portrait of characters on the edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Rowello and Hilary Swift
title: ‘Nonbinary Runners Have Been Here the Whole Time’
description: In the past year, road races have debuted a nonbinary category, typically with around two dozen or fewer such competitors at each event.
content: As a middle-distance runner for Columbia University, Jacob Caswell did not feel like they had space to be themself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Mets Have an Imperfect Night to Remember
description: Tylor Megill and four relievers shut down Philadelphia, securing M.L.B.’s first no-hitter of 2022 and the second in Mets history.
content: The Mets and the Phillies had done this before in Flushing. On Father’s Day in 1964, Philadelphia’s Jim Bunning twirled a perfect game against the Mets at Shea Stadium. Bunning needed only 90 pitches in an effort now memorialized in Cooperstown, N.Y., on his Hall of Fame plaque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Engineers Discover 19 Revolutionary War Cannons in Georgia’s Savannah River
description: The Army Corps of Engineers found one after another while dredging. The cannons are believed to be from a British ship that was deliberately sunk before a battle.
content: The first cannon pulled up from Georgia’s Savannah River surprised the workers for the Army Corps of Engineers who dredged them out of the riverbed’s clay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson
title: Kremlin Deploys New Troops to Ukraine as Both Sides Gird for a War of Attrition
description: Moscow is hitting fuel refineries and imperiling critical harvests, while Ukrainian forces are being buoyed by an influx of heavy weapons.
content: Russia is calling in troops based in its far east to join the battle in Ukraine, the Ukrainian military high command said on Saturday, as Moscow seeks to reinforce its war-fighting force amid heavy losses and signs that its drive to seize eastern Ukraine has stalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Governments Tighten Grip on Global Food Stocks, Sending Prices Higher
description: Dozens of countries have thrown up trade barriers in the past two months to protect scarce supplies of food and commodities, but experts say the policies will only exacerbate a global food crisis.
content: WASHINGTON — Ukraine has limited exports of sunflower oil, wheat, oats and cattle in an attempt to protect its war-torn economy. Russia has banned sales of fertilizer, sugar and grains to other nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Musk Joins Moguls to Kill S.E.C. ‘Gag Orders’ at the Supreme Court
description: Elon Musk joined an amicus brief that could have big implications for how the S.E.C. brings cases and whether defendants who settle can ever talk about them.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘What Are We Supposed to Cut Back?’ Britons at Risk as Fuel Bills Skyrocket.
description: Fear among older and other vulnerable people is building as war in Ukraine aggravates energy costs that inflation had already pushed higher.
content: CLACTON-ON-SEA, England — The bills are mounting for Maureen Hart, a former librarian living on a fixed income after hip and back pain from a fall forced her into an early retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore
title: What to Know About Tucker Carlson’s Rise
description: A Times examination of the host’s career and singular influence at Fox News shows how his trajectory traces the transformation of American conservatism itself.
content: Night after night on Fox, Tucker Carlson weaponizes his viewers’ fears and grievances to create what may be the most racist show in the history of cable news. It is also, by some measures, the most successful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: A small group of women and children has made it out of Mariupol’s Azovstal steel plant.
description: A Ukrainian commander and Russian news agencies said about 20 civilians were able to leave the steel factory in the besieged city of Mariupol. An unknown number of civilians remains at the plant.
content: About 20 women and children have been evacuated from Mariupol’s embattled Azovstal steel plant, according to a Ukrainian commander in the factory and Russian state media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Rotunno
title: Mother’s Day Gifts, Reframed
description: After two years that did not go as most people desired, why not give Mom something you know she will want: a framed photo.
content: For every Mother’s Day that I can remember, my mom has always asked for the same thing: a poem. The tradition started at a time when my two siblings and I were too young to earn money of our own. It stuck because my mom, like others I have met, has always preferred sentimental to splurge-y gifts, even if my stanzas could never compare to Keats or Ginsberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 4 Canadian Military Cadets Die After Car Plunges Into River
description: The men were set to graduate from the Royal Military College in a few weeks, the authorities said.
content: Four Canadian military cadets who were weeks away from graduating died early on Friday morning after their car plunged into the St. Lawrence River in Kingston, Ontario, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Looking Inward, and Back, at a Biennale for the History Books
description: Eyes are the key metaphor in the Venice Biennale’s central show of 213 artists, an unprecedented percentage of whom are women.
content: VENICE — It starts in the eyes: shy or seductive, gaping or sealed shut, aqueous frontiers between the mind and the world. There are the pupils of the German surrealist Unica Zürn, cohering out of dense, automatic black squiggles. The giant irises of Ulla Wiggen, each unique as a fingerprint and capable of unlocking a credit card or blocking passage across a border, painted in close-up on circular canvases. All over town, on palazzo-side posters and the hulls of the vaporetti, there are eyes announcing the 59th Venice Biennale: ghostly, milky corneas, drawn by the young Mexican artist Felipe Baeza, disembodied, floating in deep space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jo Hamya
title: The Double Bind of the Feminine Ideal
description: In Mieko Kawakami’s latest, a woman tries to shed her loneliness by drinking a lot.
content: Twice in Mieko Kawakami’s “All the Lovers in the Night,” a 34-year-old proofreader, Fuyuko Irie, receives a pale yellow bottle of perfume by the luxury brand Chloé. Both bottles are gifts from work friends: first the glamorous Hijiri, an outspoken neoliberal feminist who shows her affection by regularly commissioning Fuyuko for freelance jobs; and then Kyoko, an editor at the Tokyo publishing house that Fuyuko quits at the start of the novel, to work alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Justin Green, Who Put Himself Into His Underground Cartoons, Dies at 76
description: “Binky Brown Meets the Holy Virgin Mary,” his epic autobiographical story of Catholic guilt and neurosis, “made comics grow up,” a colleague said.
content: Justin Green, a star of underground comics in the 1970s who channeled his Catholic guilt and childhood neuroses into “Binky Brown Meets the Holy Virgin Mary,” a raw and intimate confessional epic that inspired cartoonists like Art Spiegelman to explore autobiographical subjects, died on April 23 in Cincinnati. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore
title: How Tucker Carlson Reshaped Fox News — and Became Trump’s Heir
description: As the host turned a civil war at Fox to his advantage, he found himself at the forefront of the nativist forces transforming conservative politics.
content: Tucker Carlson had a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: They Grew Up Legally in the U.S., but Can’t Stay After They Turn 21
description: Children of temporary visa holders who can’t gain permanent residency are one of several groups urging the Biden administration to act on an immigration overhaul.
content: WASHINGTON — In 2011, after five years of working and living with his family in the United States on a temporary visa, Barathimohan Ganesan submitted green card applications for his wife, his 5-year-old daughter and his 11-year-old son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Christian Village in Israel Digs Into Its Crusader Past
description: The residents of Mi’ilya long wondered what archaeological treasures lay beneath a crumbling castle. Now, some are excavating their homes to find out.
content: MI’ILYA, Israel — In the middle of Eilia Arraf’s home — between two living rooms, a cactus garden and a makeshift gym — there are two large pits, each containing the ruins of a church that archaeologists believe was built about 1,600 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: Abbott Threatens to Declare an ‘Invasion’ as Migrant Numbers Climb
description: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has pursued an expensive and unusual effort to harden the border. But after a year, there is little to show for it.
content: EAGLE PASS, Texas — From a camouflage Humvee at the edge of the Rio Grande, a Texas National Guard soldier on the front lines of Gov. Greg Abbott’s campaign to secure America’s southern border was watching a man with a crutch crossing the river from Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: Why Forced Addiction Treatment Fails
description: The United States needs more programs that are compassionate and inviting.
content: Jason Norelli, a San Francisco native, spent several years homeless in and around the city’s Tenderloin district, addicted to methamphetamine. In 2001, he was legally mandated to attend rehab and has been in recovery ever since. Today he helps others like him get care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Leap With a Twist
description: Joe DiPietro leads us through a cool workout.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We rightfully call attention to debut constructors, but sometimes it’s nice to take note of someone on the other end of the spectrum: This is Joe DiPietro’s 30th Saturday puzzle, and his 139th crossword for The Times. His debut was in 1995, also with a Saturday grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Neighbor Is Exploiting Our Shared Property Line. What Can I Do?
description: When miscommunications arise between neighbors, it’s often best to start with the benefit of the doubt, then escalate if necessary.
content: Q: A shared alley separates my Staten Island house from my neighbor’s. The property line runs down the middle of the alley, so we each own half of it. A gate attaches the two properties. My neighbor put a padlock on the gate, and has not given me a key. So I have no access to my property from that side — I can’t access the air-conditioning condenser and equipment. I have written to my neighbor asking for a key, but she has not responded. What can I do? If I need to make repairs on that side of my house can I cut the lock with a bolt cutter?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert and Aleksandra Koroleva
title: Civilians continue to seek refuge at a besieged steel complex in Mariupol.
description: That citizens are still seeking to shelter at the plant, where there is no prospect of escape or rescue, offers a testament to what they must be facing elsewhere in the devastated city.
content: Despite dire conditions at the Azovstal steel plant, the Ukrainian military’s last foothold in the key port city of Mariupol, civilians continue to arrive seeking shelter from Russia’s offensive, according to fighters there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Sunflower Oil ‘Vanishes’ as Ukraine War Grinds On
description: Several British supermarkets have joined other chains around the world in asking shoppers to limit their cooking oil purchases, as supplies dwindle and prices rise.
content: First the coronavirus, then the war. Just as the pandemic caused shortages of essential items, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has disrupted important food supplies, driving up prices of staples like cooking oil in supermarkets around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Willy Staley
title: Is Anna Wintour Really a Tyrant, or Something Else Entirely?
description: It depends on whom you ask.
content: In the very first pages of “Anna,” a semi-authorized biography of the Vogue editor Anna Wintour, the protagonist cries. It is Nov. 9, 2016, the morning after her erstwhile pal Donald J. Trump was elected to the presidency, and Wintour is speaking at a hastily arranged all-staff meeting. In the course of inveighing against a Women’s Wear Daily article that accused her of going too far in her support for Hillary Clinton, she cracks. This sort of peek into the soul that inhabits the iconic bob and sunglasses is what the book promises. On the cover, Wintour smirks from behind her armor, her arms crossed defiantly, as if challenging the reader to pierce the veil. The author, Amy Odell, tries valiantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Helvarg
title: Warmer Oceans Threaten Another California Forest, This One Underwater
description: These kelp forests sequester more carbon dioxide than the state’s redwood groves.
content: RICHMOND, Calif. — The bull kelp forests off Northern California are sometimes spoken of as the redwoods of the sea. And like the redwoods, these forests are in danger. In less than a decade, these otherworldly undersea landscapes, lush with life, have all but disappeared along 200 miles of coast north of San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukrainian Official Outlines Intentional Ambiguity on Strikes Inside Russia
description: The strikes have been one of the most intriguing, and opaque, new elements of the recent fighting. But when it comes to confirming their origins, “we don’t say yes and we don’t say no,’’ said the official.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — A fuel depot in Russia burst into flames, moments after surveillance video captured the bright streaks of rockets fired from low-flying helicopters. A fire broke out at a military research institute near Moscow. Additional fuel tanks have exploded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Twitter Isn’t for Quitters
description: One thing that unites conservatives and liberals? No matter how loudly they denounce the social media platform, they don’t actually leave.
content: It was the moment conservative Twitter tried to cancel itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay and Dave Philipps
title: The death of an American fighting for Ukraine is confirmed by his family.
description: Willy Joseph Cancel Jr., 22, died in combat earlier this week, according to his uncle. He is believed to be the first American killed while fighting in Ukraine.
content: A former Marine infantryman who left Kentucky to defend Ukraine in March was killed this week while fighting alongside the Ukrainian military, according to his uncle. He is believed to be the first American killed in the fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: A Memorial for André Leon Talley
description: Fashion’s luminaries gathered at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem to remember a fashion titan.
content: For many years, shortly after the flowers began to sprout, André Leon Talley would ascend the steps of a church on 84th Street and Fifth Avenue to pay homage to the gods of fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove and Eduardo Medina
title: Three Meteorology Students Killed in Car Crash in Oklahoma
description: They were returning from Kansas after pursuing a storm, officials said, when their car was pinned by a truck.
content: Three University of Oklahoma meteorology students died in a car crash in Oklahoma on Friday night on a return trip from Kansas, where they had been storm chasing, according to the Oklahoma Department of Public Safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In Northern Ireland, Divided Unionists Leave an Opening for Nationalists
description: But Sinn Fein, which is leading in polls ahead of next week’s elections, hasn’t focused its campaign on unification with Ireland.
content: CARRICKFERGUS, Northern Ireland — The sun was setting over the tidy, red brick homes in a Protestant neighborhood outside Belfast when two candidates for Northern Ireland’s legislature came to knock on doors on a recent evening. It might as well have been setting on the pro-unionist dreams of the residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Bennetts
title: The Golden Age of Air Travel Gets a Reality Check
description: Two new books trace the evolution of the industry from the perspective of women who worked in it.
content: As the so-called Golden Age of Travel boomed in the 1960s and ’70s, the airline industry left no doubt about what it was selling. The ability to get from one place to another was assumed; the real lure was the pretty young stewardesses, whose desirability and explicit availability were used as sexual bait to entice the nation’s burgeoning corps of male business travelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Thompson Walker
title: Storms, Bombs, Contagions, Pandemics and Pandemonium
description: In her new novel, “Vigil Harbor,” Julia Glass imagines a not-so-distant future when a New England town is wracked by crises.
content: A recent headline in this newspaper captured in nine words a general mood that was once confined to the most anxious among us: “There Are Almost Too Many Things to Worry About.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Stream in May
description: Next month’s streaming options include new Sally Rooney fare, “Masterpiece” and a new season of “Hacks.”
content: It’s been two years since “Normal People,” the series adapted from Sally Rooney’s novel of the same name, debuted on Hulu. Depending on how warped your perception of time is lately, that may feel like it was just last week. Or perhaps the experience of watching the show glimmers in your memory like a relic from another lifetime. I’m of the persuasion that it’s been just long enough that I’m ready for another Rooney adaptation, so I’ve been eagerly anticipating “Conversations With Friends,” which arrives on May 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Bowden
title: An Oil Tanker Is Sabotaged. The Investigator Dies. Now What?
description: In Matthew Campbell and Kit Chellel’s real-life whodunit “Dead in the Water,” Big Oil, Big Insurance and global corruption clash on a giant scale.
content: Surely the first clue that something shifty was afoot was when the crew of the oil tanker Brillante Virtuoso helped the hijackers to board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Lauren Hirsch
title: Can Elon Musk Make Twitter’s Numbers Work?
description: Financially speaking, the billionaire’s buyout of the social media network breaks all the usual rules.
content: At the peak of the buyout boom in 2007, private equity firms including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought the Texas energy giant TXU for $45 billion. It was — and remains — the largest deal of its kind in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: Berkshire Hathaway Reports Drop in Earnings, Driven by Investment Losses
description: Warren Buffett, at the conglomerate’s annual meeting, said Berkshire had been buying stock in the video game company Activision. And dissident shareholder proposals failed.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the insurance and investing conglomerate that is run by the billionaire and investment legend Warren E. Buffett, reported on Saturday a significant drop in earnings in the first quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Blank Expression
description: Brandon Koppy stuns us with an intricate Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Before you make an optometrist appointment, be advised that today’s grid is 23x23 rather than the normal 21x21. So, yes, the squares are getting smaller; it’s not you. On the plus side, that means there are more squares to love, and the breathing room makes the presentation of an extravagant multipart theme more graceful. Multipart? Yes — if you’ve solved it without finding its accompanying note: “After you’ve finished solving, look for an appropriate bonus phrase.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Some Muslims Are Using Digital Rings to Track Their Praises to God
description: Much like the fitness tools that count steps, these electronic devices help keep a record of the day’s religious recitations.
content: JERUSALEM — Walking through the courtyard of Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem on a recent afternoon, Nisreen Biqwaidar wore a pink Apple Watch on her wrist to count her steps and a green ring on her finger to count her religious recitations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Man Charged With Hate Crimes After Nooses and Racist Notes Found
description: Federal prosecutors accused Kenneth Pilon, 61, of attempting to intimidate Black Lives Matter supporters with threats in the summer of 2020.
content: A Michigan man accused of attempting to intimidate Black Lives Matter supporters by leaving nooses and threatening notes in his community and making racist threats in phone calls has been charged with hate crimes, the U.S. Justice Department said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore
title: How Tucker Carlson Stoked White Fear to Conquer Cable
description: A string of setbacks made the pundit flee television, the Republican establishment and even his home. He re-emerged with what may be the most racist, and successful, show in the history of cable news.
content: Tucker Carlson burst through the doors of Charlie Palmer Steak, enfolded in an entourage of producers and assistants, cellphone pressed to his ear. On the other end was Lachlan Murdoch, chairman of the Fox empire and his de facto boss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: When the Best Part of Going Out Is the Late-Night Snack
description: Some of New York’s nightlife scenes are less about dancing and more about eating.
content: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: These Bloodworms Grow Copper Fangs and Have Bad Attitudes
description: Scientists figured out the biochemical process that lets the turf-conscious worms grow sharp teeth using very simple materials.
content: Glycera dibranchiata is exactly the kind of creature you don’t want to find at the bottom of your beach bucket. They are called bloodworms for their translucent skin. Long and venomous, the worms are native to both coasts of North America and have four sharp fangs and a somewhat grumpy temperament: As they burrow through the sand, they will attack whatever they sense nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Inside the Flawed Vetting Process That Led Gov. Hochul to Brian Benjamin
description: An initial 63-page background check revealed two red flags in Mr. Benjamin’s past, but it failed to turn up a subpoena issued to his political campaign.
content: The first warnings about Brian A. Benjamin came early, just three days after Kathy Hochul learned she would become governor of New York and began a hurried search for her second-in-command.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Winnipeg Landmark Rich in Symbolism Comes Under Indigenous Control
description: The Hudson’s Bay Company has turned over its former flagship store to an Indigenous group with big ambitions for the space.
content: Few editions of this newsletter have prompted as many emails from readers as did the one last year about the closing of the Hudson’s Bay Company’s former flagship department store, which dominates the streetscape of downtown Winnipeg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: How to Separate Parents From Their Money
description: It takes just a kid and an app.
content: As soon as my older daughter started playing the online world-building game Roblox, she began to beg for Robux, the game’s currency, which cost real-world dollars. Having read multiple stories about how kids accidentally-on-purpose spent lots of money on add-ons like “ultra rare” or “legendary” status virtual pets, I refused to buy into this scheme. No, honey, I will not spend my hard-earned American dollars on a Queen Bee that will probably end up working at a fast-food restaurant in your adopt-me universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Fuad El-Hibri, Who Led a Troubled Vaccine Maker, Dies at 64
description: His company, Emergent BioSolutions, won a lucrative contract to produce Covid vaccines but then had to throw out millions of contaminated doses.
content: Fuad El-Hibri, whose biotech company won billions of dollars in government contracts to manufacture a vaccine against anthrax but stumbled in 2021 when, having been hired to produce Covid vaccines, it had to throw out the equivalent of 75 million contaminated doses, died on April 23 at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Can We Please Get Over Our Twitter Obsession Already?
description: The platform just doesn’t matter as much as we seem to think it does.
content: I started my Twitter account in June 2008. And after 14 years on the platform, I have a lot of feelings about it. Twitter is meaningful to me, while constantly leaving me wondering why, exactly, that is the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Feeding my desperate need to make words, one point at a time.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Trip Gabriel
title: Once Soft-Spoken, Ohio Conservatives Embrace the Bombast
description: The slugfest for the Republican nomination for Ohio’s open Senate seat has buried the brand of good-natured, country-club conservatism that was once a hallmark of the state.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Republicans running for the seat of Ohio’s retiring senator, Rob Portman, appear determined to bury the soft-spoken country-club bonhomie that was once a hallmark of the party in this state, and replace it with the pugilistic brand of conservatism owned by Donald J. Trump and now amplified by the new band of Buckeye bomb throwers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Ukraine says Russia looted ancient gold artifacts from a museum.
description: According to Ukrainian officials, Russian soldiers, aided by a mysterious expert, broke into a museum and spirited away priceless artifacts from the Scythian empire.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The heist started when a mysterious man in a white lab coat showed up at the museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: As many ambassadors left town, the pope’s emissary remained in Kyiv.
description: Through shelling, street fights in the suburbs and the flight of thousands through Ukraine’s capital, the Vatican’s diplomatic mission stayed put.
content: The first flurry of diplomats decamped from Kyiv in mid-February, well before shells began slamming into and around the historic city. The next wave of embassies packed up and left Ukraine’s capital a few weeks later, when the war began in earnest, moving their operations west and away from the fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Taylor
title: Family Saga. Capitalist Satire. Climate Thriller. Debut Novel.
description: Vauhini Vara’s “The Immortal King Rao” is about a lot of things, from a father-daughter bond to the end of human civilization.
content: The premise of Vauhini Vara’s debut novel, “The Immortal King Rao,” is as simple as could be: A young woman named Athena, raised in secret on an island in the Puget Sound by an aging father who has injected her with genetic code that allows her to access the entire internet and also all his memories, finds herself in a prison named after her mother, awaiting judgment by algorithm for a crime she insists she did not commit. While she waits, she writes a lengthy self-defense addressed to the Shareholders of the mega-corporation that has replaced the U.S. government, indeed all governments, just as “Shareholder” with a capital “s” has replaced the word “citizen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and The New York Times
title: ‘I Lost Everything’: Pakistani Airstrikes Escalate Conflict on Afghan Border
description: The airstrikes killed at least 45 people, stoking fears of a violent resurgence of the conflict in eastern Afghanistan, which has become a base for Pakistani militants.
content: MANDATAH VILLAGE, Afghanistan — It was nearly 3 a.m. in the mountainous borderlands of eastern Afghanistan when a deafening thud jolted Qudratullah awake. Confused, he staggered to the doorway of his mud brick home, looked outside and froze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: C. Vivian Stringer, Celebrated College Basketball Coach, Says She Will Retire
description: Stringer, who reached four Final Fours, won more than 1,000 games over a half-century at Cheyney State, Iowa and, finally, Rutgers.
content: C. Vivian Stringer, the Hall of Fame women’s basketball coach at Rutgers University who first commanded a college sideline in 1971 and became one of her sport’s premier defensive minds, said Saturday that she would retire in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: What Happens in Vegas Requires No Further Security, N.F.L. Says
description: Despite some recent high-profile arrests of players, the league said the security protocol for Las Vegas is the same as for any other N.F.L. city.
content: LAS VEGAS — In the last six months, at least five N.F.L. players have been arrested in this draft city known widely as a party and tourism capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Ukraine grapples with fuel shortages after Russian attacks.
description: Officials in Kyiv have urged residents to use public transportation rather than private vehicles in an effort to save fuel for the military.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Drivers lined up at gas stations across Ukraine over the weekend as the government struggled to deal with a fuel shortage caused by Russian attacks on oil infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Stay Calm Like a Monk
description: Shunmyo Masuno offers his advice.
content: Shunmyo Masuno offers his advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Yourish, Weiyi Cai, Larry Buchanan, Aaron Byrd, Barbara Harvey, Blacki Migliozzi, Rumsey Taylor, Josh Williams and Michael Zandlo
title: Inside the Apocalyptic Worldview of ‘Tucker Carlson Tonight’
description: A New York Times analysis of 1,150 episodes reveals how Tucker Carlson pushes extremist ideas and conspiracy theories into millions of households, five nights a week.
content: A New York Times analysis of 1,150 episodes reveals how Tucker Carlson pushes extremist ideas and conspiracy theories into millions of households, five nights a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Tornado Strikes Kansas Town Near Wichita
description: A tornado on Friday night ripped through Andover, Kan., damaging homes and heaving cars. No fatalities were reported.
content: A tornado on Friday night ripped through Andover, Kan., damaging homes and heaving cars. No fatalities were reported.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Rise in Young People Identifying as L.G.B.T.Q.
description: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat about culture wars and transgender health care.

title: Corrections: April 30, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 30, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about Holocaust survivors fleeing to Germany from Ukraine misstated the age of Galina Ploschenko. She is 88, not 90.
source.name: The New York Times
